The Kosambī Jātaka
“A loud noise, a gathering of people,
no one thinks they’re a fool;
When the Sangha is divided,
they don’t think anyone else is worse.
They’re confused, speaking as if wise,
talking about the domain of words;
They wish for a long mouth,
but they don’t know what they’re led by.
‘He insulted me, hit me,
defeated me, robbed me’—
Those who keep on bringing this up
don’t put an end to their enmity.
‘He insulted me, hit me,
defeated me, robbed me’—
Those who don’t keep on bringing this up

original: veraṁ tesūpasammati.🔽Na hi verena verāni,🔽sammantīdha kudācanaṁ;
analyzed: veram  na hi verena verāni  kudācana
translated: put an end to their enmity.🔽For enmity is never settled by enmity;
enmity is settled by non-enmity.
This is an ancient principle.
But others don’t understand this,
so we restrain ourselves here.
But those who understand this
are wise and put an end to it.
Those who break bones, take life,
steal cattle and wealth,🔽and plunder the country—
they too have a gathering.
